repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Economic Management and
            Private Sector Operation Project; and First and Second
            Poverty Reduction Support Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Management and
            Private Sector Operation (EMPSO) Project for Mozambique are
            as follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory; risk to the
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Ratings for the First and Second Poverty
            Reduction Support Credit (PRSC I and II) Projects for
            Mozambique are as follows: outcome was satisfactory; risk to
            the development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the projects included: 1)
            the very good macroeconomic performance sustained by
            Mozambique over the last two decades suggests that as long
            as the country is following prudent and effective
            macroeconomic stabilization and management policies in the
            context of ongoing International Monetary Fund (IMF)
            programs, it is sufficient for the Bank's assistance
            program, as has been done in the context of the EMPSO and
            the PRSC series, to base its evaluation of macroeconomic
            developments on IMF's assessment, and to provide
            ancillary support, without devoting major extra efforts
            itself across the whole spectrum within this policy area; 2)
            the experience of Mozambique also suggests that the PRSC/GBS
            modality seems to have yielded broadly satisfactory results,
            which have been at least as good as alternative modalities,
            but with the added advantage of having the country itself
            leading its development agenda and playing a central role in
            coordinating the assistance from its development partners.
            The presumption of a proven track record, while not a
            guarantee for continued success, is an important
            pre-condition. Close monitoring and evaluation by the
            country and its partners during implementation is also very
            important; 3) the experience of the financial sector and
            that of the telecommunications and air transport sectors,
            suggests that accompanying budget support, or development
            policy loan (DPL) operations, with related technical
            assistance (TA) may increase the chances for success.
            However, for more complicated sectors like private sector
            development (PSD), or agricultural and rural development,
            this may not be sufficient, and there may be a need for
            additional interventions; and 4) stability in the
            composition of Bank and counterpart project teams, and close
            involvement of staff of the Bank's office in Maputo at
            all stages of project preparation and implementation are
            important for increasing the chances of success of
            Bank-supported operations.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Economic Management and
            Private Sector Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings for the Mozambique
            Economic Management and Private Sector Operation Project
            (EMPSO) are as follows: Project outcome is satisfactory;
            sustainability is likely; institutional development impact
            is modest; Bank performance is satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance is satisfactory. The most significant lessons
            pertain to the project's consistency with the
            government's development priorities and the Country
            Assistance Strategy; the skill mix and the continuity of the
            teams assigned to the preparatory phase that led to
            delivering a good design of the project's content; and
            the need for a comprehensive assessment of the legal
            capacity of the Borrower to coordinate the implementation of
            the reforms. Besides shortcomings that were mentioned, the
            evaluation considered the financial package of EMPSO
            appropriate and the amount lent was regarded as adequate.
            The suitability of the lending instrument is "beyond
            question." Seen from the point of view of the Borrower,
            EMPSO represented an advance compared to previous operations
            since in this case there was an immediate conversion of the
            amounts of each of the two tranches into local funds for
            budget support as soon as each tranche was released.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Economic Management and
            Private Sector Operation, Release of Second Tranche - Waiver
            of Condition

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Management and Private
            Sector Operation (EMPSO) for Mozambique aimed to improve the
            management of public finances and create a better
            environment for the private sector to be the engine of
            growth of the economy. EMPSO targeted: (i) supporting the
            implementation for actions identified by the PARPA in the
            areas of public financial management and financial sector
            supervision (including both banking and non-banking
            financial institutions) to reduce the risk of financial
            crisis; (ii) improving macroeconomic stability as a
            prerequisite for sustaining growth over the medium-term;
            (iii) improving the investment climate for the private
            sector; and (iv) laying the foundation for legal and
            judicial reform, both to sustain economic growth and also to
            enable the sector to address key legal challenges of modern
            societies. The government has taken the necessary actions to
            meet fully seven of the eight specific conditions contained
            in Schedule 2 of the Development Credit Agreement (DCA), and
            the remaining condition (condition 5) has been partially
            met. This part of this memorandum describes the actions and
            outcomes achieved in each condition as they are defined in
            Schedule 2 of the DCA.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Economic Management and
            Private Sector Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Management and Private
            Sector Operation Project will support the Government's
            program of consolidating macroeconomic stability, and will
            lay the foundation for sustained private sector-led growth
            over the medium term. It includes measures to: extend budget
            coverage, and conduct a public expenditure review; resolve
            the financial difficulties of two banks, and reduce
            Government ownership in the financial sector; strengthen
            supervision in the financial sector; and, liberalize the
            telecommunications, and air transport sectors, opening these
            sectors to further, private participation. The project is
            designed to support the objectives of the Poverty Reduction
            Strategy Paper, and is part of a continuing set of reforms,
            designed to consolidate a stable macroeconomic environment,
            sustain growth, and reduce poverty through improvements in
            the sustainability of public sector delivery. However,
            categories of risk include: political risks due to the
            diminishing electoral margins of the ruling party, which
            creates a climate of risk aversion, and a possible slowdown
            in the implementation of reforms; macroeconomic risks, due
            to diminished private sector confidence in the wake of
            financial difficulties of the two partly, state-owned banks;
            and, high fiduciary risks. The project will seek to diminish
            macroeconomic risks, through reforms designed to lead
            increased transparency, and reducing state ownership in the
            banking sector; and, to mitigate fiduciary risks, the
            Government is already following the agreed action plans.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Economic Management and
            Private Sector Operation Project : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Management and Private
            Sector Operation Project is to support the Government's
            program to consolidate macroeconomic stability and to lay
            the foundations for sustained private sector-led growth over
            the medium term. One of the components is to make progress
            with the privatization of the petroleum company PETROMOC.
            The objectives of this environmental pre-audit is to: carry
            out a pre-audit of a representative number of the facilities
            of PETROMOC, and to develop a ranking to determine which
            types of facilities will need a full, partial, or no
            environmental audit or environmental assessment before
            divestiture; measure the environmental conditions of the
            facilities against risk of being held responsible for
            damages after divestiture; use the baseline information to
            assist the borrower in preparing guidelines to ensure the
            necessary audits be taken according to the ranking study;
            and review the national legislative framework to ascertain
            whether the government or the new private investors will be
            legally responsible for clean-up measures. The pre-audit
            recommends that a full audit be done for the three main and
            five smaller facilities as well as partial audits for at
            least 20 representative retail outlets and a representative
            sample of the 19 depots.

Mozambique - Economic Management and Private
